briefOverview: Jesus Christ teaches about the sacrament’s focus and anticipates a future communal meeting with key prophetic figures, then exhorts believers to put on the whole armor of God.
summary: Christ declares that the materials used in the sacrament are secondary to partaking with single-minded remembrance of His body and blood. He commands the Saints not to procure wine or strong drink from their enemies, but to use what is made new among themselves. He promises a future occasion on earth to drink the fruit of the vine with His servants, naming figures who hold priesthood keys—Moroni, Elias, John (the Baptist), Elijah, the patriarchs, Adam (Michael), and the apostles Peter, James, and John—and affirms that John and later Peter, James, and John ordained Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery. He frames this in terms of keys for the last days and the dispensation of the fulness of times, when all things will be gathered in one. The chapter concludes with a call to rejoice and to put on the whole armor of God—truth, righteousness, the gospel of peace, faith, salvation, and the Spirit—remaining unified and faithful until His coming.
externalContext: This revelation is situated in the earliest period of the Latter-day Saint movement (1830), when the Church of Christ had just been organized and sacramental wine was commonly used among Christians. Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery later reported angelic ministrations in 1829: John the Baptist conferred the Aaronic Priesthood, and Peter, James, and John conferred higher priesthood authority soon after. Latter-day Saint teachings emphasize priesthood keys transmitted by ancient prophets and apostles as part of a “restoration,” culminating in a latter-day dispensation. The instruction not to obtain wine from enemies reflects a practical concern for holiness and communal integrity amid early hostility toward the new church.
externalReferences: The promise to drink the fruit of the vine “with you” recalls Jesus’ words at the Last Supper (Matthew 26:29). The “stick of Ephraim” language aligns with Ezekiel 37:15–19, interpreted in Latter-day Saint tradition as relating to the coming forth of the Book of Mormon. The turning of hearts by Elijah echoes Malachi 4:5–6, and the phrase “restoration of all things” resonates with Acts 3:21. The armor of God imagery closely parallels Ephesians 6:10–17, while the gathering “in one” in the “fulness of times” parallels Ephesians 1:10; the “Ancient of Days” title appears in Daniel 7:9, 22, though this text uniquely identifies him as Adam.
practicalQuestions: How can I approach the sacrament so that remembrance of Christ—not the particulars of the elements—remains central?
What safeguards or practices help ensure that sacred ordinances are conducted with integrity and free from compromising influences?
Which parts of the “whole armor of God” are weakest in my life right now, and what actions would strengthen them?
How can I seek unity with others in prayer and purpose so that we are “agreed” in our petitions to God?
In what ways can I participate in turning hearts across generations—honoring ancestors and blessing posterity—consistent with this chapter’s vision?
uncertainAreas: The identity and role of “Elias” are complex in Latter-day Saint usage; here he is linked both to restoration and to the promise given to Zacharias about John. The phrase “made new among you” regarding sacramental drink may refer to freshness and/or being produced within the community; the exact nuance is not explicit.
